items.title: Additional newlines added in YAML blocks for multi-line strings
items.body:
Hello!

I've observed that `_extract_yaml_block()` performs `"\n".join(raw_yaml)` without having stripped the newline character in each possible line, resulting in unwanted empty lines when parsing multi-line strings in YAML blocks.

I'll give an example. With this file:

```python
#!/usr/bin/python3

import tap.parser

tap_input = """TAP version 13
1..2
ok 1 A passing test
   ---
   message: test
   severity: fail
   output: |+
     this is a multiline
     string but with tap
     somehow blank lines
     are added to it.
"""
parser = tap.parser.Parser()

for i, l in enumerate(parser.parse_text(tap_input)):
    if i == 2:
        print("{!r}".format(l.yaml_block["output"].splitlines()))
```

The output is:

```
['', 'this is a multiline', '', 'string but with tap', '', 'somehow blank lines', '', 'are added to it.']
```

Where as I expected:

```
['this is a multiline', 'string but with tap', 'somehow blank lines', 'are added to it.']
```

I will submit a PR shortly.

With the following TAP stream in a file:

items.title: AttributeError when not all tap files are version 13
items.body:
Small example with tappy 3.0:

```bash
$ cat version_13.tap 
TAP version 13
ok 1 test_foo
1..1
$ cat not_version_13.tap 
1..1
ok 1 test_bar
# tests 1
# pass 1
# fail 0
$ tappy version_13.tap not_version_13.tap 
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "bin/tappy", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/main.py", line 15, in main
    suite = build_suite(args)
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/main.py", line 28, in build_suite
    suite = loader.load(args.files)
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/loader.py", line 31, in load
    suite.addTest(self.load_suite_from_file(filepath))
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/loader.py", line 47, in load_suite_from_file
    return self._load_lines(filename, line_generator, suite, rules)
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/loader.py", line 69, in _load_lines
    for line in line_generator:
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/parser.py", line 116, in parse
    yield self.parse_line(line.rstrip(), fh_new)
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/parser.py", line 122, in parse_line
    return self._parse_result(True, match, fh)
  File "lib/python3.7/site-packages/tap/parser.py", line 161, in _parse_result
    peek_match = self.yaml_block_start.match(fh.peek())
AttributeError: 'itertools.chain' object has no attribute 'peek'
```

This happens because the parser sets `self._try_peeking = True` on the first version 13 file it sees, and assumes it can peek on the remaining files.

items.title: Release downstream versions that pin to a Python 2 supported tap.py
items.body: To ensure that users of `pytest-tap` and `nose-tap` don't have a broken experience for Python 2 users, both of those packages should get one last release that "pins" to a version less than tap.py 3.0.

items.title: Handle yaml.load deprecation warning
items.body: The test suite is throwing a deprecation warning related to the use of load. tappy should use safe load.

items.title: Remove mock dependency
items.body: Since tappy is dropping Python 2 support for the 3.0 release, it is safe to remove the dependency on `mock` and clean up imports in test cases and use only `unittest.mock` instead.

items.title: Drop Python 2 support
items.body:
Python 2 will be EOL at the end of 2019. tappy will drop support for Python 2 when Python 2 goes EOL.

As this will break users of Python 2, this will be a major version bump.

items.title: Add command-line interface like python3 -munitest
items.body:
It would be *really* neat if there was a way to run existing `unittest`-based test suites with something like `python3 -mtappytest`.  Something like this mostly works already:

```
import tap, unittest
runner = tap.runner.TAPTestRunner()
runner.set_stream(True)
unittest.main(module=None, testRunner=runner)
```

items.title: SyntaxError when pip installing in Python 3.6
items.body:
Hi,

I tried to rule out local configuration issues but couldn't seem to find anything wrong. Here's what happens when I try to install tappy via pip:

```
$ pip install tappy
Collecting tappy
  Using cached https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/bf/e6/26ee364e95d1fceb7291e8eb06cb7314e9c98ee11cedfebd92ade88e8f57/tappy-0.9.2.tar.gz

        raise SystemExit, msg
                        ^

    ----------------------------------------
Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip-install-8151gqbg/tappy/

```

items.title: Update copyright to 2019
items.body: tappy is alive and stable. The copyright should be updated to hint at that.

items.title: Output 'TAP version 13' to .tap files
items.body:
If version 13 is in use (or enabled) then print 'TAP version 13' to any .tap files created. Donwstream consumers in Tappy require that line to be present to attempt to load YAML blocks so it would be good for the producer to output it.

I've done this locally but have never submitted to a GitHub project before so thought I'd ask first - happy to share more details of why this would be good, or the code I've used, and also happy to submit for PR if that's easiest.

items.title: @expectedFailure decorator should result in # TODO directives
items.body:
Other TAP producers, such as Perl, report expected failures and unexpected successes like this:

```
not ok 1 - this should be equal but we have not implemented it yet # TODO not implemented yet
ok 2 - likewise # TODO not implemented yet
1..2
```

Here test 1 is an expected failure, and test 2 is an unexpected success (it was marked as an expected failure but succeeded anyway).

`@expectedFailure` currently prints `_('(expected failure)')` or `_('(unexpected success)')`. If it printed `# TODO` first, resulting in something like

```
not ok 1 - this should be equal but we have not implemented it yet # TODO (expected failure)
ok 2 - likewise # TODO (unexpected success)
1..2
```

then that would interoperate with other consumers.

items.title: Add a PR template
items.body: It at least needs to document the expectations about code coverage and being part of the AUTHORS file.

items.title: Sub tests are not included
items.body:
If the unittests include [subtests](https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html#distinguishing-test-iterations-using-subtests) the results of these subtests are not picked up.

Also, if the test class contains only failing subtests, the tap file may not be generated at all.

items.title: Info about use
items.body:
Hello,
I developed a program for testing the network behaviour (in python). In normal run it actually checks conditions and if they are not satisfied it updates an error log file.

Can I "produce" TAP file dinamically from my code?
Something like
```
tap = newTapTestCase(...)
if !condition:
  tap.addError(...)
else:
  tap.addOk(...)
tap.close()
```
Riccardo

items.title: Switch developer tooling from requirements.txt to Pipfile
items.body: Pipfile is supported as an official tool and it has some advantages over a requirements.txt workfow.

items.title: Ignore tests in coverage report
items.body: It messes with the coverage numbers and is irrelevant.

items.title: Drop Python 2.6 support
items.body: It's time to drop 2.6 support as it is a long unsupported Python release.

items.title: Remove syntax highlighting plugin
items.body:
The plugin was merged upstream. Confirm that Pygments has the latest version (I think I made some small modification to it), then remove it from tappy core to eliminate the Pygments dependency.

Update the documentation to point to the upstream plugin.

items.title: Extract nose plugin to new project
Extract pytest plugin to new project

milestone.title: Move to python-tap
milestone.description: Track issues related to the move to the python-tap organization.

items.title: Update rtd
items.body: Read the Docs changed from .org to .io.

items.title: Docs improvement: Explain plan model
Move version info into package
items.body: Help comply with PEP 0396.

items.title: Move images to docs
items.body: Use the images on the README in the Sphinx docs too.

items.title: Move release building to a Makefile
items.body: The current release process compiles the po files to mo files. Unfortunately, this force `setup.py` to include `Babel` as a `setup_requires`. This is not necessary. A simple `Makefile` could script the release building steps.

items.title: Update copyright year
items.body: It's 2016 and this project is still alive and well.

items.title: Rework developer workflow
items.body: The current development workflow does not use pip. This is pretty lame because `python setup.py develop` takes no advantage of caching. Change the flow to make better use of pip.

items.title: TAPTestRunner not observing unittest.main() buffer keyword
items.body:
The TAPTestRunner does not buffer output when the buffer=True keyword is passed to unittest.main(). I have this simple test:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
from __future__ import print_function
import sys
import unittest
import tap

class TestStuff(unittest.TestCase):

    def test(self):
        print("Some output")
        self.assertTrue(True)

if __name__ == '__main__':

    # A:
    unittest.main(exit=False)

    # B:
    unittest.main(buffer=True, exit=False)

    # C:
    runner = tap.TAPTestRunner()
    unittest.main(testRunner=runner, exit=False)

    # D:
    runner = tap.TAPTestRunner()
    unittest.main(buffer=True, testRunner=runner, exit=False)

```

Case A and case B both produce the output I expect: the message printed by the test is displayed at A, and not displayed at B:

```
# A Output
Some output
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000s
OK

```

```
# B Output
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.000
OK
```

However,  the C and D cases both display the output from the test; IMO the D case should not.

```
Some output
.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 0.002s
OK

```

items.title: tappy move to organization
items.body: tappy could probably move to an organization. Doing that would allow for an easy place to put plugins if it ever makes sense to split them out.

items.title: Include pytest longrepr error as diagnostic in tap output
items.body:
pytest outputs something like:

```
self = <tap.tests.test_result.TestTAPTestResult testMethod=test_adds_error>

    def test_adds_error(self):
>       raise AttributeError()
E       AttributeError
```

the TAP output should capture it like:

```
not ok 1 - blah blah blah
# self = <tap.tests.test_result.TestTAPTestResult testMethod=test_adds_error>
# 
#     def test_adds_error(self):
# >       raise AttributeError()
# E       AttributeError
```

items.title: Add support for Python 3.5
items.body: When Travis is ready to support this via tox, start testing it.

items.title: Consider making TAP file generation opt-in for the pytest plugin
items.body: After installing tappy, bare runs of `py.test` spam my local directory with .tap files. The only use case I have is generation of TAP streams on stdout, so IMHO, this behavior is undesirable. I should have to explicitly pass an option to tappy to have it generate TAP output of any kind.

items.title: Bad TAP filenames when using pytest's parameterized fixtures
items.body:
When using pytest's [parameterized fixtures](https://pytest.org/latest/fixture.html#parametrizing-a-fixture), pytest appends the parameter value to the name of the test. If the parameter value contains characters that aren't allowed in a filename, tappy fails when generating its report.

For example, with a test named `test_handshake_is_refused_for_mismatched_Origin` and a parameter of `"http://not.my.host"`:

```
...
File "/home/blah/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/_pytest/vendored_packages/pluggy.py", line 596, in execute
  res = hook_impl.function(*args)
File "/home/blah/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tap/plugins/_pytest.py", line 58, in pytest_unconfigure
  tracker.generate_tap_reports()
File "/home/blah/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/tap/tracker.py", line 114, in generate_tap_reports
  with open(self._get_tap_file_path(test_case), 'w') as out_file:
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'test_handshake_is_refused_for_mismatched_Origin[http://not.tap'
```

Ideally, tappy would sanitize the test name when constructing a filename for the TAP output.

items.title: Update Travis config to test on OS X
Utilize AppVeyor to test on Windows
Consider building a universal wheel package
tappy script should read from a stream
items.body: The `tappy` script is only capable of reading from files right now. It should learn how to read from streams too.

items.title: Add a pytest plugin
items.body: pytest is another popular testing tool in the Python world. A plugin to support that tool would expand tappy's reach.

items.title: Document alternatives to tappy
items.body: tappy is not for every project. The documentation would benefit from suggesting alternatives to tappy and what use cases they fit in (like pycotap for a small dependency free TAP unittest runner).

items.title: Make parser understand YAML diagnostics for TAP version 13
items.body: TAP version 13 added optional YAML blocks to tests. Everything else about the spec stayed the same. If the TAP parser was updated to support YAML blocks, then tappy could be considered version 13 "compliant" (even though YAML blocks never had any formally defined schema).

items.title: Add i18n
items.body:
tappy should be internationalized. It does not have a lot of strings which means this should be a no brainer.

The strings need to be marked up. POT file generated. Transifex account team started. Translation completed. PO file integration. Test suite updates to run through with different languages.

items.title: Support subtests, rather than multiple files, in nosetest plugin
items.body:
For my particular use case it would be much better for me to have a single .tap file that combined the multiple files into a single tap output using subtests.

```
    # tests for Foo
    ok 1 - one
    ok 2 - two
ok 1 - Foo
    # tests for Bar
    ok 1 - one
    ok 2 - two
ok 2 - Bar
```

items.title: Add a way to stream TAP instead of writing only to files
items.body:
Some systems can utilize streams to collect TAP output. tappy could suppress the standard test runner output and stream TAP directly.

The tappy default should continue to use a standard test runner output. Adding an option like `--tap-stream` could produce TAP output directly to STDOUT.

items.title: nosetests --with-tap not producing TAP
items.body:
Hello,

I'm a Perl developer looking to integrate some Selenium python tests with our build platform.  I installed tap.py and added --with-tap to my nosetests command and the output didn't change at all.  Any ideas how I can go about troubleshooting this?  I know that before I installed tap.py I'd get a failure immediately, but once installed nosetests ran, so the plugin is there, it just doesn't seem to be doing anything.  I haven't a clue.

Thanks!

items.title: Exception information when crashing in setUpClass
items.body:
Hi,
I am using tappy together with nose. In the plugin there is one thing which is not nice for debugging.
If a exception is raised in the setUpClass/tearDownClass function, the backrace shown does not show usefull information to solve the problem.

See the code below and see the difference executed with

> nosetests -s

C:\SetupTest>nosetests -s
setUp Base Class
# E
## ERROR: test suite for <class 'TestClass.Base'>

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 209, in run
    self.setUp()
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 292, in setUp
    self.setupContext(ancestor)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 315, in setupContext
    try_run(context, names)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\util.py", line 470, in try_run
    return func()
  File "C:\Users\gettert\Desktop\Nose\SetupTest\TestClass.py", line 14, in setUp
Class
    raise Exception("Big class setup problem")
Exception: Big class setup problem

---

Ran 0 tests in 0.000s

FAILED (errors=1)

or 

> nosetests -s --with-tap 

C:\SetupTest>nosetests -s --with-tap
setUp Base Class
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Python27\Scripts\nosetests-script.py", line 9, in <module>

  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\core.py", line 121, in **init**
    *_extra_args)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\unittest\main.py", line 95, in **init**
    self.runTests()
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\core.py", line 207, in runTests
    result = self.testRunner.run(self.test)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\core.py", line 62, in run
    test(result)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 177, in **call**
    return self.run(_arg, *_kw)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 224, in run
    test(orig)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\unittest\suite.py", line 70, in **call**
    return self.run(_args, *_kwds)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 75, in run
    test(result)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 177, in **call**
    return self.run(_arg, *_kw)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 224, in run
    test(orig)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 177, in **call**
    return self.run(_arg, *_kw)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\suite.py", line 214, in run
    result.addError(self, self._exc_info())
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\proxy.py", line 131, in addError
    plugins.addError(self.test, err)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\plugins\manager.py", line 99, in __ca
ll__
    return self.call(_arg, *_kw)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\nose\plugins\manager.py", line 167, in sim
ple
    result = meth(_arg, **kw)
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tap\plugin.py", line 41, in addError
    self._cls_name(test), self._description(test))
  File "C:\Python27\lib\site-packages\tap\plugin.py", line 55, in _cls_name
    return test.test.__class__.**name**
AttributeError: 'ContextSuite' object has no attribute 'test'

In the second case I get a backtrace but it does not show information which guides to the problem location.

It would be great if you could fix the problem.

See the code below to reproduce the problem.

Thanks a lot 

Wolfram

import unittest
class Base(unittest.TestCase):

```
@classmethod
def setUpClass(cls):
print("setUp Base Class")
    raise Exception("Big class setup problem")

def test_1(self):
self.assertTrue(True, "Pass everytime")
```

items.title: Update documentation for Debian packaging
items.body: @cans, if you get tappy packaged in Debian, I would love to update the documentation to mention `apt-get install tappy` (or `python-tappy` or whatever it gets called) as an installation method. It will help recognize your work and benefit the project as an easy install method.

items.title: tappy is not listed as a TAP consumer on testanything.org
items.body: Change that after 1.3 is released.

items.title: Allow the TAP producer to write a stack trace as part of the output
items.body: More of a feature than an issue, I know it is not required to output the stack trace, but it would be nice to have it.

items.title: Should allow users to define where TAP files are saved
items.body:
In the `Tracker` class:

```
def generate_tap_reports(self):
    for test_case, tap_lines in self._test_cases.items():
        with open(test_case + '.tap', 'w') as f:
            print('# TAP results for {0}'.format(test_case), file=f)

            for line_count, tap_line in enumerate(tap_lines, start=1):
                print(' '.join([
                    tap_line.status,
                    str(line_count),
                    '-',
                    tap_line.description,
                    tap_line.directive,
                ]), file=f)

            print('1..{0}'.format(len(tap_lines)), file=f)
```

I have a use case where I would like to define where the TAP files are saved, instead of saving it where the user runs the tests.

Great project btw :)

items.title: Another TAPTestRunner
items.body:
Hi. It's funny to see another TAPTestRunner implementation in Python that was released just 3 days before I committed my own version to SCons project. =)

https://bitbucket.org/techtonik/scons/commits/8d565e7a0932b23911fcb87734f2a376afacf726

The TAP protocol is old, and over all these years looks like nobody came up with Python unittest runner for it. I've chosen TAP to experiment with alternative formatting of unittest result for SCons. Maybe you will find some ideas there useful. The code is in public domain, so feel free to copy/paste.

items.title: Test suite coverage numbers are wrong
items.body: Something about nosetests and coverage is not playing nicely. When I run nosetests from within the tap directory, I get the coverage numbers I expect. When I run from the directory above, the numbers plummet. When I run nosetests through tox, it goes to zero.
